Understanding the Document

What Is a Minor Travel Consent Letter?

A minor travel consent letter is a signed and notarized document in which a parent or legal guardian grants permission for their child to travel with another adult - whether that is the other parent, a grandparent, a family friend, a school group, or an organized tour. It serves as proof that the child is not being taken without authorization.

When You Need One

  • A child is traveling internationally with only one parent - U.S. Customs and Border Protection recommends a notarized consent letter from the non-traveling parent
  • A child is traveling with a grandparent, relative, or family friend
  • A child is traveling alone as an unaccompanied minor on an airline
  • A child is joining a school trip, camp, sports team, or organized tour
  • A child is traveling domestically and the accompanying adult is not the parent - some airlines and transportation providers request documentation
  • A child is crossing an international border where the destination country requires proof of parental consent

Who Might Ask for It

  • Airlines and cruise lines - may request a consent letter at check-in or boarding, especially for international flights
  • U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) - recommends a notarized letter for any minor crossing the U.S. border without both parents
  • Foreign immigration officials - many countries require notarized or apostilled consent letters before allowing entry
  • Schools and youth organizations - for field trips, camps, and competitions
  • Hotels and resorts - some require proof of guardianship for minors checking in without a parent
What Your Letter Should Include

Contents of a Proper Minor Travel Consent Letter

A complete travel consent letter reduces the chance of problems at checkpoints. While there is no single required federal format, the letter should include enough detail for any official to verify the child has permission to travel.

Required Information

  • Child's full legal name and date of birth
  • Passport number (for international travel)
  • Travel dates - departure and return
  • Destination(s) - city and country
  • Name and relationship of the accompanying adult
  • Contact information for both the consenting parent and the accompanying adult
  • Clear consent statement - "I authorize my child to travel with…"
  • Parent or guardian's signature - signed in front of the notary

Recommended Additions

  • Medical authorization - permission for the accompanying adult to authorize emergency medical treatment
  • Insurance information - health insurance policy details
  • Allergies and medications - important medical notes
  • Emergency contacts - at least two additional contacts
  • Copy of the child's birth certificate - to prove the relationship between the consenting parent and the child
  • Custody order - if applicable, a copy of the custody agreement
Notarization Details

How a Travel Consent Letter Gets Notarized

The Notarization Process

  1. The consenting parent or guardian presents valid, current government-issued photo ID.
  2. The parent signs the letter in the presence of the notary - do not sign beforehand.
  3. The notary completes the notarial certificate (typically an acknowledgment or jurat, depending on the document language), applies their seal, and records the transaction in their journal.
  4. You receive the signed and notarized original - and a scanned copy if needed.

Note: Only the consenting parent or guardian needs to appear and sign. The child and the accompanying adult do not need to be present at the notary appointment.

Do You Need an Apostille?

  • Some countries require an apostille on the notarized consent letter before they will accept it at the border
  • Countries that are members of the Hague Apostille Convention accept an apostille as proof the notarization is legitimate
  • Countries that are not members may require a full authentication and legalization process through the destination country's embassy or consulate
  • Check with the embassy or consulate of your destination country before traveling
  • We offer apostille and legalization services - often with same or next business day processing
Know the Difference

Travel Consent Letter vs. DS-3053 Passport Consent

These two documents are often confused because both involve a parent giving permission related to a child. They serve very different purposes.

Minor Travel Consent Letter

  • Authorizes a child to travel with another adult
  • Shown to airlines, border agents, and foreign immigration officials
  • No standard federal form - you create the letter with the details that apply to your trip
  • Notarized with an acknowledgment or jurat depending on the document
  • May need an apostille for certain destination countries
  • Can be created on-site at your notary appointment

DS-3053 (Statement of Consent)

  • Authorizes the issuance of a U.S. passport for a child under 16
  • Required when one parent cannot appear in person at the passport acceptance facility
  • Official federal form issued by the U.S. Department of State
  • Must be notarized with a jurat - the signer swears the contents are true under oath
  • Valid for only 90 days from the date of notarization
  • We handle DS-3053 notarizations - see our DS-3053 page for details

Tip: If your child does not yet have a passport and will be traveling internationally, you may need both documents - a DS-3053 to get the passport issued and a travel consent letter for the trip itself.

Frequently Asked Questions

Minor Travel Consent Letter FAQ

Does a child travel consent letter need to be notarized?

Notarization is not always legally required for domestic travel, but it is strongly recommended. For international travel, U.S. Customs and Border Protection recommends a notarized consent letter when a child is traveling without one or both parents. Many foreign countries require notarization, and some require an apostille as well. Airlines, cruise lines, and border agents are far more likely to accept a notarized letter without question.

What should a minor travel consent letter include?

A properly prepared letter should include the child's full legal name and date of birth, travel dates and destinations, the name and relationship of the accompanying adult, contact information for the consenting parent, a clear statement granting permission, and the parent's notarized signature. For international travel, include the child's passport number.

What is the difference between a travel consent letter and a DS-3053?

A travel consent letter authorizes a child to travel with another adult. A DS-3053 authorizes the issuance of a U.S. passport for a child under 16 when one parent cannot appear at the passport office. They serve different purposes - and you may need both if your child does not yet have a passport.

Can you create a travel consent letter at the appointment?

Yes. We bring a laptop, portable printer, and scanner. You can use our Rocket Lawyer account or any legal document platform to create the letter on the spot - then print, sign, and notarize in one visit.

Does my travel consent letter need an apostille for international travel?

Some countries require an apostille on the notarized consent letter before accepting it at the border. Check with the embassy or consulate of your destination country. If needed, we offer apostille services with same or next business day processing.

Can I get a travel consent letter notarized the same day?

Yes. Same-day and next-day appointments are frequently available. Travel consent letters are often urgent, and we prioritize getting to you quickly. Book online or call and text (213) 933-2507.
